Start: ^Where were you night of the murder?
^What did you think of Admiral Hold?
^Ms. Tendwell, I found some letters that you wrote...

c-0: ^Well sir, that evening I busied myself cleaning the Admiral's duelling pistols when I heard a commotion in the Admiral's study. There, I overheard the Admiral and Lady Hold in a rather heated conversation. Lady Hold left the Admiral's office quite distraught.
^I escorted Lady Hold to her chambers and comforted her, after which I returned to my own quarters.
c-1: ^Suspicious, sir? I'm not sure I understand.
c-2: ^Admiral Hold was an excellent employer. He provided me with clean lodgings, a warm bed, and six shillings a week in pay. And he adored little Avery. I thought very highly of him.
c-5: ^How could you possibly have- Oh heavens. Oh heavens! Oh heavens!
^Sir, this is not what you think it is! I know the content of those letters is terribly debaucherous. But I can explain, sir, truly!
^Just- please sir, I beg you, don't tell Lady Hold. She's such a dignified lady. She would be so ashamed to discover her lady's maid speaking in such a lewd manner.

Night_Of_Murder: ^Did you hear what Charles and Theodosia were arguing about?
^Why were you cleaning the Admiral's duelling pistols?
^Do you think Avery could have been involved in the Admiral's death somehow?

c-0:
^Well sir, I was alone in my quarters last night, when I suddenly heard young Master Avery screaming.

^I was in such an awful rush to find the poor boy that- to my shame- I ran down the main staircase while still in my nightgown.

^I'm afraid by the time I found him, poor Avery had already seen the Amdiral's-

^By which I mean that the Admiral was- expired. Oh, even the thought of it- it's too horrible to bear!
c-1: ^Lady Hold has often tells me she considers it is vulgar when servants make excessive use of their senses and faculties, so I thought it especially rude to listen.
c-2:
^Well, before he- expired- Admiral Hold requested that I prepare his duelling pistols for him.

^He seemed to imply that he would have some use for them upon your arrival, though what use exactly, I couldn't say
c-3: ^Sir! ^Young Master Avery is a child! Hardly even eight years of age! To imply that he could have had a hand in good Admiral Hold's- in his- ^Well, it's simply unthinkable! And I am quite sure the noble profession of journalism would never engage in baseless speculation!

Relationship: ^How long have you worked for the Hold family?
^Did the Admiral ever treat you poorly?

c-0: ^Well sir, I came to Wenchwatch Hall seven years ago, shortly after the birth of young Master Avery. They have been remarkably kind to me.  I only hope to repay their kindness.
c-1: ^Oh no sir, Admiral Hold was very respectful, a perfect gentleman. If anything, I have treated the Admiral poorly.
^Why, only last week, I was four minutes late delivering his breakfast to him.
^I only wish that his younger brother took after the Admiral in that regard. He can at times be a bit-
^A bit- lustful, if you'll excuse my language.

Lustful: ^Has Maximillian made inappropriate advances towards you?
^Wait, you mean the gay guy in the wig?!

c-0: ^I'm afraid so. Only last week, he- he placed his hand upon my shoulder! I nearly fainted from the shock. ^But please do keep that to yourself, sir. I know Lady Hold would be terrible disappointed to discover I was involved in such an obscenity with her brother-in-law.
c-1: ^Sir Maximillian is a very happy chap, you are quite right. I was surprised too that a man of such esteem and grace could have such a- wandering hand. ^But I must admit, he has garnered a reputation for being fond of the company of women.

Suspicious: ^Did anyone in the house hold a grudge against Charles?
^Did you notice anything unusual about the body?
^Lady Hold doesn't seem very upset. Could she have something to do with the Admiral's death?

c-0:
^Well, young master Avery was admittedly somewhat displeased that the Admiral confiscated his copy of the Iliad.

^Barring that, I can't think of a single reason for anyone to dislike Charles.
c-1:
^Well, I did notice that the Admiral seemed to have something in his grasp.

^Though I must admit, I didn't look very closely.
c-2: ^Lady Hold would never involve herself in such a horrid affair! Besides, she confined herself to her room for most of the night. ^Poor Lady Hold. She would never dare admit it, but she was terribly upset over her argument with Charles. I could hear her weeping from my quarters.

Lesbians_Revealed: ^What's the big deal? It's just an ankle.
^So, you and Lavender are an item?

c-0:
^Thank you for being so kind, sir, but I know you must think, and you're quite right: I'm a harlot. A strumpet. I've turned the noble Wenchwatch Hall into a mere brothel!

^But I swear to you, those letters were a momentary lapse in judgement, and L-

^They were only ever intended for one particular person's private enjoyment. They were not intended for- public consumption.
c-1:
^You are quite right sir. I've debased myself. You must think me some sort of harlot, or strumpet, or- brothel-keeper. I've disgraced the name of noble Wenchwatch Hall.

^But I swear to you, those letters were a momentary lapse in judgement, and L-

^They were only ever intended for one particular person's private enjoyment. They were not intended for- public consumption.
c-2: ^Someone who- I care about deeply. And who cares for me in return.
^Someone without who life would be a little less colourful without.
^Sir, I know I've acted disgracefully. And I know I have no reason to ask it- but-
^Could you possibly look past this terrible indiscretion on my part?
c-3: ^Yes. Lavender and I are together. I'm sure this must surprise you. It surprised me. For many reasons.
^Lavender can be rude, abrasive. She has hardly a trace of decorum, and more often than not smells of horse.
^But she is also kind. And gentle. And she loves me. For all my flaws and inadequacies. She loves me regardless. And I love her.
^In all my years, never did I imagine that such a love such as Lavender's was even possible. But now that I have found her, I couldn't bear to be without it. Without her.
^Sir, I know I have acted shamefully. I know you must think little of me. And I know I do not deserve it. But I would ask that you find some way to forget what you saw in those letters.
^People may not understand what Lavender- what we are, and should Lady Hold- should our families find out about us-
^I fear what the consequences of their discovery might be.
^Could you possibly look past this terrible indiscretion on my part?

Lesbians_Cont: ^Don't worry. I'll keep this to myself.
^This is too juicy to pass up! It's going on the front page!

c-0: ^Thank you, sir. I can't possibly thank you enough.
c-1: ^Please, sir. I beg you. I know I've made mistakes, I know I may deserve it. But please. Please.
c-2: ^Cost, sir? I'm not sure I understand.
c-3: ^Sir, I beg you to forget you ever saw those letters. It was a momentary lapse in judgement, I swear. I will never be so reckless again!

Extortion: ^I'm blackmailing you, idiot! Haven't you ever met a journalist before?!
^I'll keep this quiet. For a fee.
Extortion_Final: ^Oh. I see. I don't mean to anger you, sir, but I have precious little to give. One week's wages is all I have in savings.
^Pay up or let the world know. Your choice.
^I'm sorry, but I need the money. I have a family. My kids need to eat.

c-1: ^I see. Very well, sir. Here. Now please. Let us both forget this conversation ever happened.

c-0: ^ Her hands are clean and unmarked.
c-1: ^ Her face is clean, though her eyes are slightly red, as though she has been crying.
c-2: ^ Her clothes are practical, modest, and well-kept.
